title: Friday, 9th December, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

So, Friday huh?

BE11:03am

Apologies for the slightly late start. I was freshening my CV to apply for this:

BE11:03am

https://www.civils...tm_campaign=Indeed

11:03 am
BE11:03am

(Hat tip to @jpjernigan on The Twitter for spotting it.)

BE11:03am

Relevant skills: ability to scream internally.

BE11:03am

But anyway! Let's get on ......

11:04 am
BE11:04am

But anyway! Let's get on.

undefined
BE11:05am

We might have a commenting problem. Some stuff seems to be disappearing into the ether.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Apologies if that happens to you. We'll catch these bugs soon, I'm sure. It's only been a decade in beta testing after all.

BE11:07am

Portrait, then.

BE11:07am

And just for a change we're going for a man in a suit.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

BE11:07am

The urbane Mr Odey. He of the £150,000 chicken coop ....

BE11:08am

... and the Chicken-licken trading strategy.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

(Bloomberg) -- Crispin Odey’s flagship hedge fund lost 9
percent in November, according to a note to investors seen by
Bloomberg, meaning the billionaire money manager is on course to
record his worst year since starting the fund more than two
decades ago.
The decline in the Odey European Inc. fund brings the total
drop this year to almost 48 percent, more than the 43 percent it
lost in 1994. A spokesman for the London-based hedge fund firm
did not reply to an e-mail seeking comment.

BE11:08am

Here's what that performance looks like in a picture.

BE11:08am

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Okay, but anyone can have a bad year right? Benchmarks are there to be underperformed sometimes.

BE11:08am

One has to take a longer term view.

BE11:09am

Such as the three year ...

11:08 am
BE11:09am

BE11:09am

Okay, how about five year?

BE11:09am

11:09 am
BE11:09am

.... um.

BE11:10am

The story here is that a man took a lot of other people's money and made a one-way bet around his own slightly illogical apocalypse theory, and lost big.

BE11:10am

As in, he was short equities and Japanese bonds on an Asian collapse.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

But also long gold! Very very long gold.

BE11:11am

Because Asian demand for gold will be certain to .... oh, wait.

BE11:11am

Miles Johnson did a good piece on this in October:

11:11 am
BE11:11am

https://www.ft.com...-8cb7-e7ada1d123b1

BE11:12am

The commenters rightly argued that Odey's probably preferable to an index hugger.

BE11:13am

At least in terms of overall price discovery, which requires someone to get it wrong.

11:14 am
undefined
BE11:14am

(@Marco: it doesn't. Negative there too.)

BE11:15am

And so, to domestic matters.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

FTSE edging higher, uninterestingly.

BE11:16am

Up 0.2 per cent at 6,946. Mediclinic of all things leading, for reasons I haven't been able to pin down yet.

BE11:17am

And Capita, of course, still in its residency at the top of the fallers.

11:16 am
Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 474.42, down 10.88 (-2.24%), High: 476.10, Low: 431.30, Volume: 5.37m
BE11:17am

Quite a lot of capitulation post yesterday's profit warning

BE11:18am

(@worcesterwoman: Thumbs up )

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The phrase "selling the family silver" appears in about six notes on Capita this morning.

BE11:20am

Some genuine surprise that Andy Parker's dumping the steady, good margin financial services stuff just to protect a divi that's uncovered by earnings.

BE11:20am

Here's Barclays.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

So another outsourcer bites the bullet in order to delever. Is it just unfortunate coincidence that nearly all the big UK outsourcers have suffered the indignity of having their accounting policies scrutinised, a string of contract disputes or issues resulting in multiple profit warnings, or is there a systemic issue across the sector? The latter is a function of contract complexity and risk – both of which have increased over the years, at a time when competitive tension has increased forcing the major players to offer more for less. What is also very clear is that big is not beautiful in this market. Both Capita and Serco increased their scale and scope through aggressive M&A in order to access broader market opportunities in adjacent market areas away from their historical core. That strategy is now in reverse. Sadly for Capita, they are selling the wrong bit, in our view. Post material downgrades, Capita trades on c9.2x FY18e (post disposal) PE with a c8.1% FY17e FCF yield. This is the cheapest Capita has ever been in PE terms both relative (now 50% discount to FTSE-Allshare) and absolute. On an EV/ EBITDA basis c7x seems low, but the average across the outsourcing peer group is just 7.5x (on which our revised 525p price target is based). A near term re-rating is unlikely until growth stabilises and the strategic fog clears – but neither is likely for another 6-months in our view.

BE11:21am

Strategy on the hoof? Only this time last year Capita was in the frame to buy Xchanging, and in February, Asset Services was highlighted a key part of Capita's organic growth plans. How times change. We find the strategic rationale for selling Asset Services particularly underwhelming. It appears to be a fire sale of one of their highest quality businesses which is seen as preferable to an equity raise or a dividend cut. Fortunately, it is a good asset and they should get a good price for it, with a clean exit. But management credibility is now on the line and investors may speculate on possible management change next year. This carries additional uncertainty.

BE11:21am

Oh wow! I forgot about Xchanging! Lord amighty ......

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Forecasts cut again. Since January we have reduced our FY17e and FY18e EPS forecasts by 29% and 35% to 55.9p and 53.3p respectively. FY16e forecasts reflect management guidance of -1% organic and £515m of PBT profit erosion. For FY17e we model -3% organic with underlying margins down again, as revenue decline absorbs £40m cost savings and £20m one-off reversals. We assume a mid-year disposal of Asset Services & other non-core business for £800m (c12x EBITA), reducing net debt/ EBITDA to less than 2x, by the end of next year.

BE11:22am

And Stifel ......

BE11:22am

The fall in the bid pipeline to a 6 year low took us by surprise and suggests it will be a long grind to return the business to growth. We had hoped for a placing to strengthen the balance sheet, instead CPI is selling its crown jewels. The outcome of the business review lacks substance and our confidence in the management team's ability to turn round CPI is low. More decisive action is required. We downgrade to HOLD. The dividend yield provides some support to the share price but we see few reasons to get involved given on-going earnings risk.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Another reset of guidance with organic sales decline of -1% FY16 and -2% FY17. The pressure points are unchanged with continued weakness in the IT Enterprise Services segment and various trading businesses. With organic growth of 5% in 1H, the rebased FY guidance implies a fall to c.-6% in 2H16. Looking to 2017, reflecting known attrition and new contract wins YTD, guidance is for organic sales decline of 2% and profits flat year on year. There will understandably be scepticism from investors regarding earnings trajectory for the foreseeable future given recent trends (at the 3Q update organic growth of +1% was guided for FY16). The material fall in the bid pipeline, from £5.1bn in July 2016 to just £3.8bn which is a 6 year low, took us by surprise. The cabinet is bare with little in the tank for next year. Cost actions will provide some support to the bottom line with £50m of savings targeted by FY18 of which c.1/3rd will be reinvested in the business. We reduce our FY16 & FY17 earnings estimate by 6% and 8% respectively.

BE11:23am

We think CPI would have been well advised to raise funds from shareholders, strengthening the balance sheet at a stroke. Instead it is selling the crown jewels. FY16 net debt guidance is unchanged (c.£1.9bn) but reflecting lower profits leverage is now expected to be 2.9x (2.7x previously). We had argued in our last note for a placing to settle investors' nerves and prevent doubt from lingering on. Instead, CPI will be disposing of its Asset Services business (excl. retail banking & mortgage services). This is a high growth, high margin segment. At the FY15 prelims the virtues of this business were singled out and lauded. The rationale now is that it doesn't fit the strategy to be a more focused tech enabled BPO business. We expect strong buyer interest with proceeds upwards of £700m (10x EV/EBITDA) reducing leverage to c.2x. We estimate c.12% dilution to group EPS from the disposal to c.54p in FY17.

BE11:23am

Concerns over strategy and leadership. Our BUY case had been predicated on a very modest re-rating on the expectation that CPI's business review would deliver a credible plan to stabilise the group. However the output of this exercise, a reduced group with a focus on technology enabled BPO services, is a partial answer. We are no closer to being confident the business can return to predictable growth. Leadership matters and we have no confidence in management delivering. Downgrade to HOLD, TP 500p representing 8x FY16 earnings.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

And Shore.

BE11:24am

Following yesterday’s FY trading update (effectively a further profits warning, in our view) we publish research this morning setting our revised forecast models with downgraded expectations. In essence, we cut our FY2017F adjusted EPS forecast from 63p to 50p, so a 20% downgrade. We focus upon the strategy from the company which we believe prioritises maintaining the dividend - through selling assets to reduce debt and build balance sheet reserves. However, our model suggests that free cash flow available for strategic development and debt reduction post the dividend payment is set to remain under pressure. We retain a negative view on Capita therefore and would use any recovery in the share price to exit the stock. We note that from a technical position, Capita may now be looking at an exit from its FTSE100 status at the current share price. We retain a SELL stance.

BE11:24am

You get the idea, right?

11:24 am
undefined
BE11:25am

...... Okay.

BE11:25am

Quite a bit of noise around Sky all of a sudden.

11:25 am
Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 812.50, up 23 (+2.91%), High: 812.50, Low: 790.00, Volume: 2.39m
BE11:26am

It's been ticking higher by 2 or 3 per cent a day all week.

BE11:27am

And there's been lots of industry-level speculation around regarding 21st C Fox's intentions.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And we highlighted at the end of last month, I think, that Sky is (was) trading at a discount to Murdoch's 2011 rejected nil-premium offer in dollar terms.

BE11:30am

....... Sorry, typing a bit slow because I'm trying to piece together various emails from various folk.

BE11:31am

Let's just say there's no specific story around in Sky right now, but a spike in buy calls might suggest that someone somewhere is hoping there might be sometime in the future.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

And since we're on uncooked RAW ............

BE11:32am

Ben's done the Stada story: https://www.betavi...rs-circle-sources/

BE11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily you know.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Ben says Stada "reviewing strategic options" after receiving informal expressions .......

BE11:34am

.... names Novartis, Sun Pharma and Mylan.

BE11:34am

The way we heard the rumour, it was Mylan that made the approach and was rejected.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

But to emphasise that, we heard it was rejected. And we've had had no indication whatsoever that there's a live process now.

BE11:36am

So, this might be very very stale. Or entirely wrong, possibly. Either way, it seems unlikely to trigger any kind of statement.

undefined
11:38 am
BE11:38am

(@dunoon: dude, it's been an exceptionally bad year for RAW. The word's gone from meaning uncooked to meaning barren.)

BE11:38am

Okay, back to news. Or what little we have.

BE11:39am

DMGT slotting a load of Euromoney

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Which gives us a wee bit more clarity on the new chap's strategy, albeit not much.

Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC (ERM:LSE): Last: 1,052, down 68 (-6.07%), High: 1,070, Low: 1,000, Volume: 13.10m
Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT:LSE): Last: 781.00, down 11 (-1.39%), High: 782.50, Low: 766.00, Volume: 214.67k
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Have some Liberum.

BE11:40am

DMGT announced last night the reduction of its stake in Euromoney from 67% to 49%. The sell-down will be achieved by a combination of a placing by DMGT of its shares in Euromoney and a buyback of DMGT’s shares in Euromoney by Euromoney, with the proceeds being used to pay down debt. DMGT stated previously it made sense to own either 100pc of Euromoney or to sell its stake. Accordingly, we believe DMGT may look to sell more of its stake in the future and use the those proceeds to fund deals in events or information. Keep the BUY.

BE11:41am

The sell down of the DMGT stake will raise c. £358m in proceeds. Our view on why now is (1) it will allow Euromoney to be more flexible in its strategy without the need to take DMGT's consolidated balance sheet into account and (2) it suggests DMGT will look to make acquisitions in a relatively short time.

Given DMGT's comments in the past that it made sense to own either 100pc of Euromoney or to sell its stake - but not to stay at its then present stake - it suggests that DMGT may look to sell down more of its stake in the future, with the ERM stake (worth £704m for the 49pc stake as a % of market cap) being used as a funding pot for future deals.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

DMGT stated it would use the proceeds from the sale to reduce net debt, but we think it will use the cash to more likely do deals, if only to offset the dilutive effects of the sale down (if DMGT used the proceeds to sell down debt only, it would be 6% dilutive to FY16 numbers - see below how to calculate) although, by deconsolidating ERM's stake, it does mean that DMGT's leverage post-sale goes from 1.8x at YE15 to 1.7x.

BE11:41am

The sale gives a clear indication of DMGT's strategy - stated by new CEO Paul Zwillenberg - to focus on fewer strategic areas but to deepen its exposure to those with high growth potential. We would therefore expect more steps. In our view, one area to look out for is Events where DMGT has a well regarded but relatively small events unit; and further deals that would fall under the DMG Information banner.

BE11:41am

We think a portfolio re-organisation is almost inevitable in FY'17, whilst new CEO Paul Zwillenberg, at the last analyst presentation, did not divulge which assets they would specifically like to focus on he wouldn't rule out the sale of any. There were some clear hints to which assets Mr. Zwillenberg sees as core to the future of the business. We think these include the DMG Information assets specifically Xceligent, Hobsons and Genscape as well as MailOnline. Outside of these assets we believe some or all of them could potentially be divested. Management stated there was going to be a change to DMGT's M&A policy, previously DMGT would fund acquisitions from disposals but there is going to a shift to funding acquisitions through their FCF generation. Consequently, management may focus on maintaining the businesses within the portfolio that exhibit attractive cash flow dynamics.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

(@ROTR, assuming you're still there on a key corporate Christmas lunch Friday. Do you subscribe to Euromoney? Do you know anyone who does? Have you ever seen a copy?)

BE11:43am

... And Goldman Sachs.

BE11:44am

While we see the sale of the Euromoney stake as improving DMGT’s financial flexibility and scope for potential M&A, we note that this increases the group’s exposure to the media business (c.47% post the sale vs c.36% previously), which continues to be impacted by the structural decline in print advertising and will also be adversely affected by cost inflation in € sourced newsprint which we believe will be a c.200 bp headwind to DMG Media Margins in FY17. We are Sell-rated on DMGT and value the stock on a SOTP valuation methodology, giving us a 12-month price target of 576p. Risks to our thesis include: (1) stronger-than-expected print advertising; (2) faster than-expected growth in RMS or MailOnline; (3) value-enhancing M&A; and (4) favourable FX movements.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

And Barclays ..........

BE11:44am

Moving Euromoney from being fully consolidated to being an associate is not straightforward. In the P&L, in FY17 we are forecasting £102m of EBITA for Euromoney and £24m of minorities. Assuming the transaction were to go through as described, those two would have to be removed from the P&L and replaced by 49% of £102m in the Associates line. Euromoney has a slightly higher tax rate as well, so there would be a modest tax benefit in the process. Running that process through the FY17 P&L implies a negative impact to EPS of 7-8%.

The impact on free cashflow would likely be significantly higher. Currently, as discussed in detail in our note Downgrade to Underweight (25 November 2016), DMGT includes within the DMGT FCF: 1) 100% of Euromoney's FCF, less 2) dividends to the Euromoney minorities at a payout ratio of around 45%. So in FY16, Euromoney FCF was £82m but DMGT paid out £13m to minorities in dividends, so the net number in the FCF from Euromoney was £69m. As we forecast a very similar EBITA in FY17 and the same dividends to shareholders number, that is the same approximate number that we include in FY17 FCF from Euromoney. But treating it as an associate, DMGT would be set to receive just 49% of Euromoney's dividend. As part of their release, DMGT refers to a plan to get Euromoney to increase its dividend payout ratio. Even if we assumed that Euromoney were to pay out 60% of FCF as a dividend, that would still mean a contribution to DMGT's FCF of only: £82m (of FCF) 0.6 = £50m (total dividends paid out) 0.49 = £25m (the amount that DMGT would be entitled to).

So the Euromoney contribution to FCF would move from £69m to £25m: £44m lower. We forecast £176m of FCF for DMGT in FY17: 44 / 176 = 25%. So we estimate that this move should reduce DMGT's FY17 FCF by 25%.

BE11:45am

Euromoney consensus net cash in FY17 is c.£90m and our forecast for DMGT net debt fully consolidating Euromoney in FY17 is £615m. So stripping out Euromoney's cash, our net debt would be £705m. Currently Euromoney's market cap is c.£1.4bn. Leaving aside the issue of what price the placing and buyback might be done, the difference between 67% of that and 49% is 18% * 1400 = £252m. So the DMGT net debt less the potential cash from the sale would mechanically be £453m.

In terms of EBITDA inc associates, under the new regime discussed above, EBITDA would lose about £106m of Euromoney EBITDA (fully consolidated) and gain £52m of associates. Our current EBITDA inc associates is £384m. This would reduce by £54m to £330m. So that would make FY17 net debt/EBITDA 1.35x vs 1.60x in our current forecasts. So the gearing would reduce (and headroom increase) but not by a dramatic amount.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

In summary, this proposed deal to sell down part of DMGT's stake in Euromoney could potentially be quite dilutive to FY17 EPS and very dilutive to FY17 FCF, creating a hole that would be difficult to fill with the headroom created. But we accept that this does indeed show the new DMGT CEO starting to work on the portfolio, which most investors agree is not currently optimal. That does look a positive for the story, even if it comes at a fairly heavy cost to the financials.

undefined
BE11:47am

(@Erlkin: feel free to point us to whichever story we're not covering in this newsless vacuum of a Friday.)

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Sepura? Not much to say, I think.

BE11:47am

Deadline moves out to Dec. 16.

BE11:48am

Discussions said to be "positive", rest is the usual "no certainty" boilerplate.

11:48 am
Sepura PLC (SEPU:LSE): Last: 19.84, up 0.091 (+0.46%), High: 19.75, Low: 19.00, Volume: 1.31m
BE11:49am

Live price is flat.

BE11:49am

No-one on the sellside seems interested. Not enough to publish on it anyway.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

The other smallcap bid news of the day is Fyffes, of course.

BE11:50am

Inventors of the hovercraft.

BE11:51am

(I'll make the ML hovercraft running joke work if it's the last thing I do, goddammit.)

11:51 am
BE11:51am

( https://ftalphavil...tslive/2016-04-01/ )

BE11:51am

(Erlkin: gold down 0.5% live.)

BE11:52am

Have Goodbody.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Sumitomo Corporation and Fyffes have announced this morning that they have come to an
agreement for the acquisition of Fyffes plc. The cash offer has been unanimously
recommended by the Fyffes board. In addition, 27% of the shareholder base has also given
its irrevocable support to the deal. Subject to shareholder approval at the EGM, the deal is
expected to close in Q1’17.
The Japanese conglomerate has offered €2.23 per share or a market capitalisation of
€751.3m. In addition, shareholders will be paid a dividend of 2p per share. The offer
represents a 49% premium to yesterday’s close and a 37% premium to its all-time highs.
The offer values Fyffes on an FY17 PE and EV/EBITDA of 16x and 12.5x respectively.

BE11:53am

Sumitomo Corporation is a leading Japanese conglomerate with a €15bn market
capitalisation and net cash on the balance sheet of €8bn. The business consists of 800
companies and has been involved in the banana industry since the 1960’s with a market
leading position in Asia. At present the Group represents c.30% of the bananas imported into
the Japanese market.
While the Fyffes board believes the Group is well positioned to continue its growth, the offer
from Sumitomo represents a compelling premium which realises a lot of its future potential.
Fyffes will benefit from the greater scale, reach and resources of a much larger group. The
two Group’s also have highly complementary business as the largest banana distributors in
Europe (Fyffes) and Asia (Sumitomo).

BE11:53am

Overall, the offer looks attractive for Fyffes shareholders. With almost 30%
support from existing shareholders, we expect the deal to complete smoothly.

11:54 am
Fyffes PLC (FFY:LSE): Last: 187.00, up 58 (+44.96%), High: 187.00, Low: 187.00, Volume: 828.34k
undefined
BE11:56am

(@Erlkin: Lincoln upgrade was yesterday ....

11:55 am
BE11:56am

BE11:56am

(Honsestly, I'm not being snide here. I'm just saying there's nearly nothing with which to fill this hour of knockabout stocks fun.)

BE11:57am

Nearly there! What else?

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Merrill's downgraded Barclays but I don't have it to hand because Merrill is going through one of its regular phases of not liking us.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 233.53, down 5.47 (-2.29%), High: 238.35, Low: 231.00, Volume: 21.97m
BE11:59am

... Morgan Stanley's positive on S&N, and doesn't seem to not like us yet.

11:59 am
Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,155, up 25 (+2.21%), High: 1,164, Low: 1,144, Volume: 1.38m
BE12:00pm

We upgrade to Overweight as SN is likely to see accelerating organic sales growth and margin leverage opportunities through 2017, while it trades on an attractive EV/EBITDA multiples. We expect a recovery in organic sales growth driven by: 1] Advanced Wound Management and the launch of Renasys Touch; 2] China destocking ending supporting Sports Med, Trauma and Woundcare; and 3] tender orders returning in the Gulf states. Furthermore as SN transitions past the headwinds of 2016, which limited EBITA margin expansion, we expect 2017 to benefit from top line growth without the drag from dilutive M&A and a negative FX impact. In addition to strong operational performance, we see upside optionality from M&A, as SN is able to utilize its balance sheet as it approaches a net cash position in 2017-18. Given both strong sales growth and operational leverage in 2017, valuation looks attractive on EV/EBITDA, with the shares on 9.2x 2017e, a 20% discount to the orthopaedics peer group. Key risks include: 1] Potential repeal of ACA could impact US utilization rates in the US; 2] Failure to deliver on margin expansion opportunities due to unforeseen issues in SN’s increasingly complex portfolio.

BE12:01pm

That's part of a bigger med-tech note.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

(@Soundbuy: you'll remember Stryker admitted on the record that it was weighing a bid, then changed course and did a buyback instead. I think the rumour died of natural causes.)

BE12:02pm

NVESTMENT THEMES: LOTS TO CONSIDER
1] Potential US Obamacare repeal may negatively impact utilization and capital equipment providers, such as Getinge and Elekta; 2] Potential US tax reform would boost corporate profitability, especially for heavy US earners, such as Fresenius Medical Care and Essilor. 3] FX should provide an earnings tailwind from a stronger USD; 4] EU political debates are likely to make headlines, including German elections, French elections and the start of formal Brexit negotiations, all of which could create market turbulence and support flows into the MedTech sector.

BE12:03pm

OVERWEIGHT: SALES GROWTH RECOVERY, ACQUISITIONS & US TAX RATE
1] Organic Sales Growth Recovery: Essilor and Smith & Nephew should benefit from an improvement in organic growth and margins. 2] Acquisitions: Fresenius SE's Quironsalud acquisition, rather than Kabi, should dominate the debate. 3] Strong Product Cycles: Straumann's recent share price weakness provides an entry point into the FY17E potential of BLT implant and value offering. We like Qiagen, where growth should benefit from new product roll-outs including QIAsymphony and QuantiFERON TB. 4] Macro Considerations: Fresenius Medical Care's US earnings exposure is ~75% of group, making it a major beneficiary of potentially lower US tax rates. BPCI & ESCO profitability should help to fuel earnings growth in FY17E.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

UNDERWEIGHT: STRUCTURAL & EARNINGS HEADWINDS & POOR EXECUTION
We are UW stocks that may face structural headwinds or poor execution. Elekta continues to restructure, while the radiation oncology market is struggling to grow. Getinge execution has been challenged by CEO/CFO changes and negative organic sales growth, and high gearing is unhelpful. Grifols faces an earnings headwind from COGS inflation.

BE12:04pm

....... All of which hit desks before the FDA said it was looking into over-the-counter hearing aids.

BE12:05pm

Basically, if I get the story, talking about buyers of OTC hearing aids having to have a medical evaluation first. Which seems reasonable, surely?

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Sonova, William Demant both lower on it. Anyway ....

undefined
BE12:06pm

Gee whiz, look at the time.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

In answer to the ROTR, PM will still be in Mozambique next week.

BE12:07pm

Who takes a holiday for the fortnight preceding the week before the Christmas-New Year shutdown? PM does, that's who.

BE12:08pm

So, there's every chance I'll be doing this solo again. Do join. Or not. Whatever. I'll be here whichever way.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Back Monday. Afternoon, all.

BE12:08pm

(@Otter: we might liveblog the Queen's speech.)

BE12:09pm

(Otter: disclaimer: we won't.)

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Which has been going around all week.
